## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 23, 2020 - December 29, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-31T14:20:47Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-12-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201231-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-12-23T03:00Z-06:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity corresponds to a continued enhancement in the solar wind speed following the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-12-21.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-12-24T14:05Z and stayed elevated above background levels for the remainder of the reporting period (see notifications 20201224-AL-001, 20201224-AL-002, and 20201226-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-12-21.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate during the reporting period due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-01-05T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Two active regions (12794 and 12795) are visible on the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole structure visible in the northern hemisphere of the Earth-facing disk may become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-26T17:02:22Z
## Message ID: 20201226-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt.  GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 1000 pfu starting at 2020-12-24T14:05Z (see recent notification 20201224-AL-002). The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2020-12-26T16:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-12-21T23:10Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-12-24T14:05:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 16, 2020 - December 22, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-24T02:13:34Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-12-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201224-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-12-21T21:00Z to 2020-12-22T00:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-12-21.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)

None Observed

Earth directed:

None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-12-29T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be at low levels during the outlook period. Active regions 12792 and 12793 have decayed to plages and are expected to rotate off the Earth-facing disk. An unnumbered active region and active region 12794 will continue rotating onto the Earth-facing disk during the first half of the outlook period as seen in the available EUV imagery from STEREO A and SDO. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The large coronal hole structure extending from the north pole of the Earth-facing disk may continue to be geoeffective during the beginning of the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is expected to be elevated during the outlook period in response to the coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-12-21.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 09, 2020 - December 15, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-16T20:47:42Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-12-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201216-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during the reporting period.  There was one C-type CME (see details below). The CME event is likely associated with a B1.4 flare (peak time at 2020-12-13T08:55Z) from AR12793 located at S18E90. Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling, it was estimated that this CME may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2020-12-15T15:03Z (plus minus 7 hours)(see notification 20201216-AL-001). The analysis for this event was delayed due to the lack of coronagraph imagery available during the day of occurrence. 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-12-10T00:00Z-03:00Z. This Kp value is associated with the combined arrivals, detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1, of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-12-09 and the arrival of an interplanetary shock at 2020-12-10T01:29Z. The interplanetary shock is likely associated with the CME first seen in the coronagraphs around 2020-12-07T16:24Z (see notifications 20201207-AL-001, 20201207-AL-002, 20201208-AL-001, and 20201210-AL-001).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low during the reporting period.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2020-12-13T09:24Z     ~610            C              -121/3                 26                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-12-22T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. Currently, there are two numbered active regions with low magnetic complexity visible on the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low levels during the outlook period. A large coronal hole structure extends from the north pole coronal hole of the STEREO-A-facing disk and could become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period. A large, diffuse coronal hole structure can be seen across the central Earth-facing disk and could result in intermittent to sustained coronal hole high speed streams during the outlook period. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-16T17:24:36Z
## Message ID: 20201216-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2020-12-13T09:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~610 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -121/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2020-12-13T09:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe.  The leading edge of the CME may have reached Parker Solar Probe at 2020-12-15T15:03Z (plus minus 7 hours).

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2020-12-13T09:24:00-CME-001):

## Notes: 

This CME event (2020-12-13T09:24:00-CME-001) is associated with B1.4 flare with ID 2020-12-13T08:47:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2020-12-13T08:55Z. The analysis of this CME event was delayed due to a lack of available coronagraph imagery on the date the CME event was initially observed.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-10T13:55:57Z
## Message ID: 20201210-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to geosynchronous orbit starting at 2020-12-10T04:24Z.

The activity is associated with CME with ID 2020-12-07T16:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20201207-AL-001, 20201207-AL-002, 20201208-AL-001) and  Interplanetary Shock with ID 2020-12-10T01:29:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20201210-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2020-12-10T04:24:00-MPC-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 02, 2020 - December 08, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-09T21:33:56Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-12-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201209-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during the reporting period. There was 1 O-type CME (see details below). This O-type CME was first observed by STEREO A COR2 at 2020-12-07T16:24Z and is associated with a C7.4 flare from active region 12790 which peaked at 2020-12-07T16:32Z (see notification 20201207-AL-001). Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling, it was estimated that this CME may reach Mars at 2020-12-10T09:43Z (plus minus 7 hours) and is expected to impact NASA missions near Earth. The leading edge of the CME was predicted to reach NASA missions near Earth around 2020-12-09T05:23Z (plus minus 7 hours), with the roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index of 5-8 (minor to severe) (see notification 20201207-AL-002).

Based on additional heliospheric ensemble modeling the CME is expected to impact Mars and missions near Earth. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicated that the leading edge of the CME would reach Mars between about 2020-12-09T21:38Z and 2020-12-10T20:32Z (average arrival 2020-12-10T06:38Z) for 100% of simulations, and NASA missions near Earth between about 2020-12-09T00:55Z and 2020-12-09T14:45Z (average arrival 2020-12-09T06:54Z) for 100% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 76% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 5-7 range (minor to strong) (see notification 20201208-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=2 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period (see notifications 20201202-AL-002 and 20201202-AL-003) and stayed somewhat elevated for the rest of it. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 on 2020-11-30.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were elevated above background levels at the beginning of the reporting period in response to the M-class flare and O-type CME mentioned in last week's report (see notification 20201202-7D-001). The 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A became elevated above background levels again towards the end of the reporting period in response to the C7.4 flare and O-type CME described above.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the radiation belt enhancement mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-12-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-12-15T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There are a few active regions visible on the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and strong levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole structure visible to the west of the center of the Earth-facing disk in SDO AIA 193 in the past few days may become geoeffective within the next few days. Additionally, the anticipated arrival of the 2020-12-07T16:24Z O-type CME at Earth around 2020-12-09 is expected to elevate geomagnetic activity.

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 25, 2020 - December 01, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-12-02T21:49:08Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-11-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-12-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20201202-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during the reporting period with one M-class flare (see list below).  There were two C-type and one O-type CMEs (see details below).  The first C-type CME was associated with an eruption beyond the northeastern limb of the Earth-facing disk and first seen by SOHO C2 at 2020-11-26T21:24Z from active region AR12787 at N32E90.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling, it is estimated that this CME may affect Parker Solar Probe around 2020-11-29T14:12Z and a glancing blow to STEREO A around 2020-11-30T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20201127-AL-001). The second C-type CME was associated with a filament eruption from active region AR12787 and first seen by SOHO C2 at 2020-12-01T05:48Z.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars around 2020-12-06T07:51Z and STEREO A around 2020-12-03T12:35Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20201201-AL-003 and 20201202-AL-001). The O-type CME was first observed by STEREO A COR2 at 2020-11-29T13:24Z and was associated with a M4.4 flare that peaked at 2020-11-29T13:11Z and an eruption from the active region beyond the southeastern limb estimated at location S23E97 of the Earth-facing disk.  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars at 2020-12-02T22:37Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2020-11-30T19:37Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2020-11-30T19:37Z, and STEREO A at 2020-12-01T09:46Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20201129-AL-001, 20201130-AL-004, 20201201-AL-001).  The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a possible glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth.  Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2020-12-02T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). Analysis is still ongoing to determine if this CME was detected at Earth. STEREO A IMPACT instruments detected the arrival of the O-type CME described above around 2020-12-01T07:25Z.  

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were above the threshold level of 1000 pfu during the first half of the reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that started on 2020-11-22T16:40Z and were further enhanced by a coronal hole high speed stream that was detected at L1 around 2020-11-26. Solar wind speeds reached values of 470 km/s on 2020-11-26.

The flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected by STEREO A initially exceeded 0.1 pfu/MeV starting at 2020-11-30T04:26Z and is associated with the M-class flare and O-type CME mentioned above (see notifications 20201130-AL-001 and 20201130-AL-002). Proton fluxes were further enhanced to higher levels at 2020-11-30T14:16Z and may be associated with the possible arrival of the 2020-11-26T21:24Z CME (see notification 20201130-AL-003). The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES were below threshold levels for the entire reporting period, but became elevated due to this activity. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the continuing radiation belt enhancement and solar energetic particle events mentioned above.

The solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. Several active regions are visible on the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO. Active regions 12786 and 12790 have been active in the last few days.  

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period with possible arrivals at Earth of the 2020-11-29T13:25Z O-type CME around 2020-12-02 and the 2020-12-01T07:12Z C-type CME around 2020-12-04. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2020-12-02T14:10Z (see notifications 20201202-AL-002 and 20201202-AL-003) and could remain elevated during the outlook period.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2020-12-01T07:12:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20201201-AL-003). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A and Mars. - STEREO A between about 2020-12-03T16:57Z and 2020-12-04T08:30Z (average arrival 2020-12-04T00:32Z) for 100% of simulations.

The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-3 range (below minor to below minor).
